DOC.HEAD: Source Says Bush Warned Gorbachev on Baltic Violence
DOC.TEXT: President Bush told Mikhail S. Gorbachev at the Malta summit that using force to block non-violent independence movements in the three Baltic Republics would damage U.S.-Soviet relations, a senior administration source said Tuesday. ``I think the Soviet leadership understands our position on this very clearly,'' said the U.S. official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Meanwhile, an emigre Baltic diplomat who was briefed by U.S. officials on the discussion said he was told that Gorbachev responded that violence would not be used under his reform. However, Gorbachev made no specific promises on the Baltics, whose independence he has opposed, the diplomat said. Secretary of State James A. Baker III received similar assurances from his Soviet counterpart in September. The conversation at Malta was significant because the independence movements are gaining strength. The United States never recognized the Soviet annexation of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia after World War II. Under Gorbachev's reforms, those three republics, with a combined population of 7 million, have been striving for independence. Gorbachev has said that post-war Soviet borders cannot be changed. Bush's conversation with Gorbachev was not disclosed in the days immediately after the Dec. 2-3 summit, but representatives of the three emigre Baltic governments were briefed Monday by Assistant Secretary of State Raymond Seitz. By warning Gorbachev against the use of force, Bush assisted the Baltic independence movements, said Stasys Lozoraitis, charge d'affaires at the Washington legation of the Lithuania. The exile governments of the three republics have maintained legations in Washington since they lost their independence. ``If they do not use violence, we can slowly and carefully do what we need to do,'' Lozoraitis said. Leaders of the Lithuanian popular front Sajudis are predicting a victory in February elections to the republican parliament and plan to use their majority to secede from the Soviet Union, a step that is legal under the Soviet constitution. The administration source said that Bush and ``the secretary of state have made clear our legal position, that we do not recognize the incorporation, and that their status ought to be a matter of self-determination. We have no particular view as to the outcome.''' A key point of the U.S. position, said the source, was that the process ``should be peaceful.'' The exchange on the issue at Malta, the source said ``wasn't really a dialogue. It was a presenting of views.''
